Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Decision Aids for Hip and Knee Osteoarthritis

Trial_Design.evidence: A multisite 2 × 2 factorial randomised trial was conducted at three sites from April 2016 to December 2017.

Participants.evidence: 1,636 patients were randomised to receive either a long, detailed DA or a short, interactive DA.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either a long, detailed DA or a short, interactive DA.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated the comparative effectiveness of two decision aids (DAs) in facilitating informed patient-centered decisions for patients with hip or knee osteoarthritis considering surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the rate of informed patient-centered decisions, assessed before and after the surgeon visit.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by site, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Participants and clinicians were not blinded, but the statistician was.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 1,636 patients were randomised.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 1,220 pre-visit and 967 post-visit surveys were returned.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The informed decision rate was 67.2%, with no significant difference between DA groups (p = 0.97) or surgeon groups (p = 0.23). Knowledge scores were significantly higher in the short-DA group (mean difference = 9%; p < 0.001).

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial is registered at ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT02729831).
